answers.author: Adam Helms
answers.text:
In Hamilton, OH we have a separate police and city page.  All city departments (except police) are centralized on one page.  We decided to let the police have their own page because they post pictures of wanted criminals on their page and we didn't to promote the city as a whole with a collection of criminal mug shots.  However, we do post police material that may be of public interest on the city's facebook page as well (i.e. annual report, safety academies, etc.).

answers.author: Sally Spaulding
answers.text:
I would suggest having a separate page for your police no matter what. They simply have different messages and a different audience than a general centralized page would have. However, I discourage some City of Aspen Departments from having their own page and ask them to contribute information to the central City page instead. (No one wants to follow the Parking Dept. on FB, but for other departments, it makes sense for them to have a public presence in this medium.) My rule of thumb: if you don't have something interesting to post for the public each day, you shouldn't be on Facebook with your own page.

answers.author: Robert Cole
answers.text:
Hi, Katie!
Oak Park uses one FB account for all departments and solicits informational items for posting. We have 2,278 fans right now and it seems that maintaining one FB page is a sufficient commitment of Village resources without expanding it to to or more pages that require regular postings and associated monitoring. As for OPPD, they provide updates via their webpage and other communication tools.
We love our FB page and fans! Check us out at http://www.facebook.com/#!/vopnews
Have a great holiday season and I hope all is going well in Woodridge.
Best,
Rob
